reviewText:
Classic Zelda-like platformer.

After a 3-hour playthrough, I came to the conclusion that the game was okay.

Its biggest downfall is how imbalanced the magic system is. Cure-3 makes every boss fight completely trivial in that you don't have to dodge all that many things, which should be the whole point of the battle. Personal discipline in not abusing overpowered mechanics can net a lot more enjoyment out of this game.

The level up system was also fairly lackluster in that it really feels like an unnecessary feature - the HP stat is statistically garbage, the magic stat can be abused to be overpowered.

Those complaints aside, it's a solidly assembled title that works, for its price of $2. If the price were much higher, I'd have probably marked this as a negative review, but $2 is enough to let some non-game-destroying flaws slide, for a game that can offer a decent challenge with mostly working mechanics.

reviewText:
A top-down 2D Action-RPG.  The main draw of the game is how over-the-top the protagonist is.  It's not uncommon for you to learn spells and get equipment by threatening some NPC and then after getting said upgrade, to kill them.  The entire game is played out in this tongue-in-cheek manner and I found it amusing enough, though some will no doubt find it to be a bit try hard.

The artstyle is crude and bland at times and dungeons are a bit long and boring to traverse, but the dungeons have save points so replaying long stretches of them shouldn't be much of a factor.  Puzzles are rare and quite simple when they show up.

The best aspect of Evil Quest gameplay-wise is how easy it is to become a walking flamethrower.  Magic regenerates over time, so if you level-up and make it a point to pump intelligence, by the halfway point of the game you can constantly spam spells as you walk around and it trivializes most enemies.  I don't find this a downpoint since combat is rather simplistic and mowing down enemies with various spells is fun enough.

The game is pretty short, you probably won't end up with more than a half-dozen hours at most on a playthrough, though that's about right and it ended just as I was tiring of it a bit.  I had fun with this and the price point puts you in position of not having much to lose by taking a chance on it.

reviewText:
EvilQuest is a satisfying revival of action-adventure RPGs of the 8- and 16-bit. This game reminded me most of Crystalis on the NES, though it also has some similarities to Lagoon on the SNES. The map designs are similar as are some mechanics (jump boots.) Early on, the combat is fairly easy, though you may fail if you attack recklessly. Positioning and timing are most important for success, but, unlike the earlier action-adventure RPGs, enemies appear to have predictable cooldowns on their projectiles and abilities, making it far less likely you'll get surprised.

The controls are responsive, however you can perform only one action at a time like in the older games previously mentioned. The one thing that sets it apart is that you can move and turn your character while attacking, allowing you to control quarter- or half-circle sweeps with your weapon; otherwise, every attack is a forward jab. Opponents can do this also, which can catch you off-guard when flanking a foe.

While formulaic, it's a tried-and-true recipe. I recommend this to anyone who enjoys the genre and art style.

reviewText:
EvilQuest is a fun Action RPG in a 16 bit SNES style, similar to games like Zelda.  Story wise the big difference is this time rather than trying to stop the generic EVIL bad guy bent on world domination you play as the EVIL bad guy bent on world domination.  The story is fine and the EVIL twist makes it all feel fresh even though its about as simple as a RPG story gets.

The gameplay consists of attacking enemies with swords and such, holding down the attack button for a projectile attack, and some different magic attacks that you can find while exploring, or buy if you save up enough gold.  There are plenty of armor pieces to find to make you stronger, and accessories that make you more powerful in various ways, even a cape that makes you invisible.

The graphics look good for a 16 bit style, some of the enemies are merely reskined as you progress in the game, but others like dragons and ghost make for a nice visual treat as you make your way thru the game.  The levels are all based on elements like fire and water and look and play nice enough with just enough exploration to give the game some meat.  My only complaint is enemies respawn after you slightly move away from an area, so you can't clear a level per say, the enemies are always respawning.  This dose give you plenty of opportunity to gain exp points and level up, but as the game wares on it all gets a bit repetitive, but at about 5 hrs for a diligent explorer EvilQuest isn’t long enough for this to become a problem.

Overall EvilQuest is a very fun ARPG that lets you experience the generic RPG story of those 90ies RPG's from the eyes of the bad guy and plays like a dream.  For the cost of less than a gallon of gas (in the US at least) this game is an absolute steel and should be played by anyone who likes Zelda like ARPG's or wants to be EVIL.

reviewText:
EvilQuest is an action adventure RPG in a retro style. It comes off as something like a late NES or early SNES/Genesis title... if that perspective helps. You are a very powerful, evil dude that gets betrayed by his army and locked up. However, you escape captivity and go on a quest to regain your mighty power and ultimately seek to destroy God himself. Sounds pretty cool, right?

You basically go around overworlds seeking towns and dungeons. You can do some generally mean things along the way, but you're focus is to find four elemental things and then go to the final area once the barrier is broken. It's some standard, by the books stuff. But it works. Along the way, you fight through monsters and bosses in a Zelda-esque fashion. Defeating them will net you gold, which can be used to purchase equipment to make yourself stronger and items to recover from loss of health, loss of magic, or status ailments. As you progress, you'll find stronger weapons and different spells to help you tackle your foes. Also gained from defeated enemies are experience points. Getting enough of these will allow you to level up. Upon gaining a level, you have the option to distribute a number of points into whichever stats you see fit. This can be fun for building a specific way for different playthroughs. Want to beef up your magic skills? Maybe you want to deal mighty blows with your weapons. Or perhaps you just want to be a well rounded warrior. It's nice for some customization and replay value, yet not too complicated as to overwhelm the player. I also would like to point out that I thought the music was alright, but I do enjoy the art style quite a bit. Guess I'm a softy for that kind of thing.

However, every game has its faults, as does EvilQuest. I can't complain too much with the main character being bad, as it is not often done still and keeps things a bit interesting. I guess I just wish they had maybe gone a little further with that idea. Maybe that's just me. My biggest complain comes from some expectations that were built up a bit and never capitalized on. Near the start of the game you get the charge ability, letting you shoot a projectile from your weapon at no cost to magic. You then use this to hit a switch through a wall and open a gate. A little while later is a switch puzzle, where some need to be up and some need to be down. Ithought this would mean there would be cool puzzle elements throughout the game like in Zelda games. However, there weren't much more like that to be found. I guess I was hoping it'd break up some of the grinding and killing, but I guess I didn't need to grind so that part was my own fault. My most minor and rather meaningless complaint is that, in order to get all the achievements, you have to play the game twice. Yet there seems to be only one achievement that absolutely forces you to do it. The one based on difficulty. If you play on normal, you have to beat it again on hard. Also, if you play it on easy, you'll get no achievement, which doesn't make much sense. But it's all in the achievements so it's really not even an issue with the game itself. Hardly worth mentioning but... I did. So... sorry.

It's a cool retro-inspired action adventure RPG. If you like Zelda games and the RPG leveling stuff, give it a look. The game is only two bucks normally, and even less when it goes on sale. It's very much worth the price. This could possibly have passed for a ten dollar game, five at the least. But the fact that it's only two bucks makes it hard to pass up. Sure, it could use some more stuff in it, but the things included are good, especially for that asking price. So go ahead and get your copy. Forget the hesitation and go for it.

EvilQuest gets a 6/10. Everything is solid. It may not be the longest, most fleshed out, or most impressive, but what it does offer is quite a good experience and well worth the price.

First of all, I had to think long and hard about whether to give this an overall thumbs-up or thumbs-down.  I finally concluded that since I put in the time to not only finish it but get all achievements, and for all its faults it was only made by two guys it seems so it's somewhat forgivable, that it had *just slimly* earned a thumbs-up.  That being said...

WHAT THIS GAME IS:

An action-RPG straight from the NES era, very specifically based heavily on Crystalis to the point at which it's basically a poor man's copycat of that game in every way.  I would suggest skipping this and going to play Crystalis if you like the basic gameplay but want to waste as little time as possible, but if you love Crystalis and want more just like that you might as well give this game a try.  When all's said and done, the gameplay itself is actually quite fun with some fairly well-designed boss battles.

WHAT THIS GAME IS NOT:

Deep in any way, shape or form.  The artwork is laughable, the music is horrendous (some of the worst I've ever heard in any game, indie or not; do your ears a favor and turn it down on the main options screen before you even start your game) and the story is nonexistant.  Oh, sure, it has the barest-bones skeleton of what could have been a unique story, taking the role of a villain rather than a hero on a quest to destroy the world rather than save it, but the entire thing is presented in such a paltry manner it would be considered mind-numbingly boring and predictable even by 80s video game writing standards.  And if you're looking for some kind of character depth or heel-face turn or the actions of your character to mean anything beyond basic evil instincts, look elsewhere.  This game's all about being utterly and remorselessly evil, your character starts out as a more twisted take on a Saturday morning cartoon villain and only gets more evil from there.

Aside from the fact that I feel the art, music and writing are all inadequate even for an indie game made by two dudes, the attempts at humor fall short and there's a bit much killing and implied ♥♥♥♥ for a game that's meant to be a throwback to the simple, charming early era of Japanese RPGs.  Again, it teeters ever-so-closely to the edge of getting a thumbs-down; however, that basic element of gameplay is fun enough, especially for an action-RPG junkie like me, that it's the game's saving grace.

There are myriad ways in which this could have been done better, even with such a small team and null-budget; the most fitting comparison I can think of is Breath of Death VII, which is a similar type of NES RPG throwback that had a bit more competence put in the art, MUCH more care and attention put into the music, and writing that doesn't nearly mar the experience with the mentality of a 14-year-old boy who draws dudes getting disemboweled in his spare time; in fact, the follow-up to BoD, Cthulhu Saves the World, displays a much less clashingly unpleasant idea of a villain bent on world-destruction being the hero; it's played up in a much more over-the-top and cartoonish way that fits this style of game much more than the weirdly grisly and depressing 'evil guy' outlook deployed here.  But I'm getting off-track.

Basically, its quality is sub-bargain-bin in almost every way, it's as deep as a dried-up puddle and it's quite short at that (over half my 'gameplay time' here is leaving the game on AFK, and that's with going through it twice for all achievements) but the basic elements of gameplay are so fun in a simple and straightforward kind of way that if you're into this kind of thing you'll probably find it worth the asking price, ideally if it's on sale.  The main point to take from this review is these guys can and should do better next time

The Good: It's not a terrible retro RPG. If you want it to be EXACTLY like it used to be, you'll probably be happy.

The Bad: The default control scheme for pure keyboard is made for someone with more than two hands. Instead of using WASD or Directional keys and clustering the actual controls together, they're all over the keyboard: Enter/Return is attack, Z is magic, X is equipped item. The Ugly: Save points. I don't care how retro you're going, save points are a design sin.

This game isn't a timeless classic, and it won't win any prestigious awards. It IS, however, a fun action RPG that offers a decent challenge with a surprising amount of flexibility in play style. It's everything you would expect from an intentionally retro-style game. The graphics and music bring up those good old nostalgic feelings, but EvilQuest stands apart from similar games because of its dedication to its story. While most gamers may be tempted to overlook the story for its simplicity, I found it to be wholly satisfying.

Without spoiling too much, I'll say that EvilQuest's story trashes the Good VS Evil in favor of an Evil VS All approach, and it works really well. I found myself caring about what happens next and who the protagonist would encounter. Think about that. These days, it takes a dash of something special in a game to make you actually care about what happens to the people in it, and EvilQuest has that spice.

If you want a quick game with a moderate challenge and a rewarding story, you'd do well to grab EvilQuest. Don't sleep on this one.

Having just finished the game on hard, I can safely say that for anyone who has any interest in Crystalis or similair action RPGs to give this one a try. It's not perfect but it does satisfy the fun I had playing the old 16 and 8 bit games of this nature. Also you get to play from the bad guy's perspective. Too many times games that take this route either wimp out and either A: make you really a misunderstood good guy or B: make your enemies even worse then you are. EvilQuest does neither, you're just straight up evil. That being said the rest of the writing is a bit off. It seems at times that the game isn't sure whether it's tounge in cheek or deathly serious. You'll have some humourous dialouge in one scene that's way over the top and in the next be talking to someone whose family was murdered and ♥♥♥♥♥. It can be off putting to say the least.
Gameplay also has its ups and downs. Everything controls very well and the spells in the game are very satisfying to use but they also bring up one of the other downsides. The spells are extremely overpowered. Seriously just dump your points in intelligence and you can whip through this game even on hard. While this is a downside I can't deny there being a certain perverse glee in wiping out a whole screen of enemies and eating the bosses for lunch half-way through the game.
The one thing that really bothers me though are some of the enemies (mostly the bosses) hitboxes. This ones kind of hard to explain but it's the worst on the first boss a giant knight. I was standing behind him but for some reason his helmet was hitting me and killing me because the game thought I was touching him. This problem occurs in a few other bosses and considering that this wasn't a problem in actual SNES titles it's a bit unforgiveable here. In fact I almost quit right there but I am glad I didn't as the game is much better then its opening dungeon would suggest.
All in all give this one a try. Despite its downfalls it is still one of the better retro style" games out there in a sea of similair games that are much worse. Cheers

I recommend this game, mainly because of the price. If not for that, it wouldn't be worth owning. EvilQuest, is not the kind of game that is fresh, or new. Many of the retro styled games at least try to advance on old ideas; whereas this one is a blatant copy of one of my favorite titles, Crystalis. The charging of your weapon, to the layout of the overworld. There is however a refreshing feeling I have, when playing it. It may be a copy, but it is done quite well. Sure, one could argue, that the sprite design is poor, and cheesily bad. But then again look at LJN; they were charging full game price, and most of their games were hardly playable. One area 'EvilQuest' tries to advance, is the story. Now, back in the old times of NES, and SNES, we were always forced to play as the 'Hero'. This was the way things were; and it worked, damn well, at that. This was the golden age; the stories were good, the gameplay was majorly addicting, and the sprites were done so well, that we could literally see them pop off the screen. Evilquest does some of these things right. But I digress. The story is one area where they advanced, as we get to play as the villian, for once. You start out as a reknowned antagonist named, Galvis. He is all sorts of evil badassery. We are only told this through the title, game trailer, and some of the dialogue. Thus, it is the weakest point in the game. When all you are killing is monsters in the overworld; how can you call your game, EvilQuest? Seriously, this is my only real annoyance. 6/10 Great price, somewhat good title.

EvilQuest is Zelda-like ARPG.The most intriguing thing here for me is you are the villain. It's breath of fresh air. The story is simple. You are Galvis – dark knight, who wants to kill the good guys, take over the world and annihilate it. For that purpose, he needs the Chaos Axe, but it's protected by four seals and Galvis have to destroy them. This isn't oscar winning story and I don't consider it a bad thing. The guy wants to destroy the world – nice and simple.

The graphics are retro pixel art and you won't find much options here. Sliders for music, effects, difficulty setting, auto save, flash effects, fullscreen and resolution. 1280X720 pixel is the maximum here and this is the biggest issue. But I have one problem, but it might be isolated case. My PS2 controller is not compatible with the game. But mouse and keyboard setup works perfectly. And you can rebind keys.

Like I said in the beginning, this ARPG. You can attack only in four directions and the starting weapon is a knife. Soon after you start the game you will gain the ability to charge a shot, by holding the attack button for a few seconds. This is essential for surviving. In addition to shooting enemies from a distance, this will help you push hard to reach levers. There are three charge levels. Longer you hold, more powerful will the shot be.

As the game progresses, you will find new weapons. They are connected with your quest. Every new weapon is more powerful than the old ones, so you don't need to use the previuos.

If the game have only weapons, I wouldn't recommend it. But fortunately, you can use magic. They are pretty standard – fire, lightning, ice, water and earth. Every spell have two levels and they differentiate in their animation and usefulness. My favorite is Earth 2. When you are in a tight place with multiple enemies, a giant rock start ricocheting in the walls and damage everyone in the process.. You learn the spells from certain people, but if you missed someone, you may be abble to buy some of the in the shops.

The level design is nothing special, pretty standard for old school game like this. But the environments are different – dungeons, volcano, grassfield and so on. While wandering, you will find villiges. There you will buy new gear, hearbs for restoring life, mana, antidotes, spells, sleeping, learning about places you have to visit, searchis houses and so on.

Map exploration is recommened. Beside gaining xp by killing enemies, you will find treasure chests with money, herbs, gear and others. That way part of the money will be saved for something expensive.

Enemies are also typical for the genre – ghosts, soldiers, lizard-like people, bats, rats and so on. A lot of them are just reskin of each other. What I mean is the attack pattern are the same. Of course, there are other with totally different attacks or combine two. The AI is basic, but it works. As a hole it's okay.

Enemies constantly respawn, so you don't have to search for them to gain XP. After leveling up, you will receive different amount of points and you have to put them in 4  skills – strength, vitality, intelligence and toughness. You can't put more than 2  in one place. There is one thing I don't understand. What defines how much point I get? Sometimes I earn 4, other 2 and then 3. As far as the bosses, all I can say is they are ton of fun and you need different approach for each.

Sound design is good, it' on the level of older 16 bit games. Every sound of weapons, magic, the effects as a hole, remind me of them. The music is the one thing I don't like that much. It's just not memorable for me.

I had a lot of fun and this fun cost only 2E or your regional equivalent. You'll get great game, especially if you are into Zelda-like games. It took me little more than 4 hours, although Steam says 7. The dev done a great job of recreating 16 bit game. It's almost perfectly polished for what it is, aside from the low resolution. I recommend it. There is EvilQuest 2 on the way and it looks better in every way. Can't wait to get my hands on it.

I'm not usually into 8 bit styled games or anything of the like but Evil Quest certainly overides that. The gameplay is absolutely spot on with great combat, story, characters and general gameplay.

Combat: While it is a simple swing your sword (or axe) type of game, it requires just enough timing that it isn't on the end of SUPER HARD OMG I CANT HIT ANYTHING or everything just keeps dying there's no challenge! With different enemies ranging from projectile shooting ones to just regular (easier) ones that only do damage when you touch them, it makes you learn the enemies. There's also magic with many different spells throughout and a charged projectile attack so make things easier on those annoying bosses.

Story: It's a fairly straightforward story but provides an interesting direction to the game. Many of the conversations that Galvis has with other characters provides for interesting content and quite a bit of humor.

Characters: Aside from Galvis, the other people in towns provide information on direction in the storyline, just enough info that you'll have to pay attention but nothing overly detailed that's confusing so you can get right to the next part.

Gameplay: From herbs and potions to spells and weapons, there are quite a few items that can be bought and gathered to increase your stats (attack, defense, all that). The leveling up system in this is also spot on. There's never a time where things are too easy or too hard due to the perfect balance. Certainly bosses can be difficult (as are any enemies you don't understand yet) but once you get the pattern, it's just the right challenge for your level.

Overall, great great game, easy to get into and well worth the price.
